content.user_title: Create seeded generative art in p5.js
content.value_statement: You need original generative art that is reproducible and interactive. This skill guides you to craft a philosophy and a p5.js sketch with seeded randomness and parameter controls.
actual_capabilities: Provides a p5.js sketch structure with seeded random and noise initialization
Includes a parameter object pattern with update and regeneration hooks
Supplies an interactive viewer with seed controls, sliders, and color pickers
Offers a responsive layout for a sidebar and canvas container
Includes utility helpers for palettes, mapping, easing, and canvas export
limitations: Requires a browser environment that can load p5.js
Does not deploy or host the generated viewer
Does not guarantee specific visual outcomes or styles
Does not provide external asset downloads or libraries

use_cases.title: Seeded art experiments
use_cases.description: Build reproducible flow field or particle sketches with adjustable parameters.

use_cases.title: Teach generative systems
use_cases.description: Show students how algorithmic philosophy maps to p5.js systems.

use_cases.title: Interactive art demos
use_cases.description: Create a self contained viewer to explore variations for a concept pitch.

prompt_templates.title: Starter flow field
prompt_templates.scenario: New user wants a simple generative sketch
prompt_templates.prompt: Create an algorithmic philosophy for a calm flow field and outline the p5.js system with seeded randomness and three parameters.

prompt_templates.title: Particle trails
prompt_templates.scenario: User wants moving particles with trails
prompt_templates.prompt: Design a philosophy for particle trails in a vector field and define parameters for count, speed, and trail length.

prompt_templates.title: Concept seed
prompt_templates.prompt: Use the concept of tidal rhythms as a subtle seed and produce a philosophy and p5.js plan that expresses it through forces and cycles.

prompt_templates.title: Advanced multi field
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a high craft philosophy for dual interacting fields and specify a p5.js architecture with seeded randomness, palette control, and regeneration.

output_examples.input: Create a philosophy and plan for a seeded flow field with adjustable density.
output: Philosophy names a movement and explains how noise and particles create emergent structure
Plan specifies seeded randomness, particle count, and noise scale controls
Viewer includes seed navigation and palette pickers for exploration

best_practices: Use seeded randomness and noise for reproducible results
Keep all tunable parameters in a single object
Separate update logic from rendering for clarity and performance
anti_patterns: Copying specific artist styles or protected works
Removing seed controls that enable reproducibility
Using unbounded particle counts that freeze the browser

faq.question: What platforms are supported?
faq.answer: Any modern browser that can run p5.js and standard HTML and JavaScript.

faq.question: Are there output limits?
faq.answer: Outputs are templates and guidance, not pre rendered images or hosted files.

faq.question: Can I integrate this into my app?
faq.answer: Yes, embed the viewer HTML and p5.js code into your project.

faq.question: How is my data handled?
faq.answer: No data storage or external transmission is included in the templates.

faq.question: What if the sketch runs slowly?
faq.answer: Reduce particle counts, simplify calculations, or lower canvas size.

faq.question: How does it compare to static art tools?
faq.answer: It focuses on procedural systems with reproducible variation, not static image editing.
